column4: I am new. May I post my question here? It's regarding a laptop with no floppy or CDROM, but has net conn. and can boot from 64MB USB Memory Stick.

I want to install Ubuntu on the only laptop my boss would give me -- it has only a net conn. and 64MB usb mem stick. The hard drive has -- uck -- Win XP. I want to format the hard drive and replace it with Ubuntu.
that should be possible
i'm not sure if there's a mini ubuntu installer, but you could install debian and use that to "upgrade" to ubuntu
last I checked, the debian net-install cd is 40 mb or so
yikes. What if I create a mini USB linux, get some IP, format /dev/hda1, mount nfs to a remote Ubuntu CD, download bytes, then reboot and begin the install?
that should work
I have Ubuntu CDROM 5.04 with me, so no need to download over my DSL connection.
I also have several Linux and Win systems on a DHCP net here that can help me, each with CDROMs.
I've never done it, but I know you can use pxe boot to install debian
I was thinking in the interest of time, plus the fact I don't have Debian on me and would have to download over DSL, that it might be better to come up with another solution.
take a look at this:  http://ubuntuforums.org/archive/index.php/t-29358.html
Thanks for the article. The article got me thinking...Here's my response...
I can get Windows to connect to another system with CDROM. And then I could download the whole thing to the drive.
ah, ok.  then what?  boot off of the usb drive and mount the iso ?
sounds like a plan, right?
yeah, should work
in fact, I could boot from PCDOS on 64MB USB mem stick pretty easily, I bet.
yeah, should work.  :-)
Or would I need to boot from a USB linux and then run from there?
i think that if you were to boot with freedos off your usb thingy, you should be able to get it to work as in that article
